respStmt.resp: Compiled, edited and annotated by Didier Willis

availability.p: This material may be distributed only subject to the terms and conditions set forth in the Open Publication License, v1.0 or later (the latest version is presently available at http://www.opencontent.org/openpub/).
Distribution of substantively modified versions of this document is prohibited without the explicit permission of the copyright holder.
Distribution of the work or derivative of the work in any standard (paper) book form is prohibited unless prior permission is obtained from the copyright holder.

notesStmt.note: Various contributions by Jim Allan, Helge Fauskanger Per Lindberg, Elena Liria, Javier Lorenzo, David Salo, Lisa Star, Emanuele Vicentini.

sourceDesc.p: This file is automatically generated from another electronic document.

projectDesc.p: Dictionary based on J.R.R. Tolkien's books, and extended with etymological notes, phonetics and other information.

samplingDecl.p: Phonetics are transcribed using the X-SAMPA scheme for representing the IPA in 7-bit ASCII encoding.
Hypothetical words, either interpreted, reconstructed or deduced from mutated forms, are all marked as deduced.

correction.p: This document has been extensively checked, although a few casual errors or typos may still remain.
XML file validated with Richard Tobin's RXP software.

interpretation.p: Probable errors in the sources have been corrected and marked with the <corr> tag.

entry.note: LotR/II:IV, LotR/VI:IV, S/428, SD/129-31, LB/354, Letters/308
See ah for the form that this conjunction might take before a vowel

trans.def: man, one born later than the elves, a human being (elvish name for men)

entry.note: This might also be *gachas, mutated in composition

trans.def: man, `one of the Second People' (elvish name for men)

entry.note: Tolkien changed this word several times, see gaear
Tolkien changed this word several times, see gaearon

Some scholars believe this word to be cognate to Quenya nai "may it be". Others think that it is the pronoun "they". The context in which this word occurs (The so-called "King's Letter") is not clear enough to intepret it with certainty
Tolkien changed this word several times, see aear, gaear

trans.def: (unknown meaning, `song about the sea' or possibly `holy song')

entry.note: The title Athrabeth Finrod ah Andreth is translated as "converse of Finrod and Andreth", but some scholars actually believe this word to be unrelated with the conjunction a, ar "and", and they render it as "with". Other scholars consider that "and" and "with" (in the comitative sense) are not exclusive of each other, and regard ah as the form taken by this conjunction before a vowel

trans.def: name of a flower, bell-like and running through many soft and gentle colours; also used for another small white flower

entry.note: LotR/V:IX, Letters/402, UT/55, UT/303, UT/316, UT/417

trans.def: `uprising flower', referring to the flower or floreate device used as crest fixed to the point of a helmet

entry.note: With suffixed article and elision in aglar'ni Pheriannath

trans.def: long-mark, sign used in writing alphabetic tengwar, over a vowel to indicate that it is lengthened.

entry.note: Helge Fauskanger notes: the element and `long' would normally be preserved before r-, but d is lost because there is another d in the word (VT/41:9); however, this second d later disappeared in the change from -nd to -nn, and it is unclear whether or not an- would then revert to and-

trans.def: one of the `Longbeards' (a tribe of dwarves)
long rune-rows (extended version of the Cirth)
a verse mode, lit. `long-shorts' (alternance of long and short vowels)

entry.note: Ety/376, S/428, LotR/VI:IV, LotR/E, LB/354, Letters/308

A literal interpretation of the Etymologies would class this word as a noun, but David Salo notes that the punctuation in The Etymologies is not always reliable. Noldorin anw cannot be cognate to the Quenya noun hanu (*3anû) because the final -u would drop. It must rather be cognate to the Quenya adjective hanwa (*3anwâ) attested under the stem INI, where it is also stated that inw, corresponding to Quenya inya "female", has been remodelled after anw. The combination of these two entries, along with the phonological evidences, clearly indicates that anw is actually an adjective

trans.def: to follow, etym. `to walk behind, on a track or path'

entry.note: In WJ/387, the verbal stem is given as aphad-, and the etymology as *ap-pata. If we follow the latter, the verb should perhaps read aphada-

trans.def: king (used of a lord or king of a specified region)

entry.etym: Reduced form of CS aran, element in the names of the kings of Arnor and Arthedain

trans.def: king (used of a lord or king of a specified region)

entry.note: Ety/360, S/428, LotR/II:IV, LotR/VI:VII, SD/129-31, Letters/426

trans.def: innumerable, countless, endless, without reckoning, numberless

entry.note: Emyn Arnen, Lonnath-Ernin LotR/V:I, WR/294, WR/370

Originally, Lonnath-Ernin might have been intended to mean `royal havens', assuming the second element to be a regular adjective. However, the second element in Emyn Arnen `hills of Arnen' is singular. Either we must assume a semantic shift to `hill (of) royal water', or we have to understand it as an oblique construct `hill (of the) royal (one)' (by comparison with Bar Erib, conceivably meaning `home (of the) lonely (ones)'. See also arn

trans.def: `kingsfoil', a healing herb brought to Middle-earth by the Númenóreans
a dim shape, spectral or vague apparition

entry.note: Used as a negative adverb before an imperative: avo garo "don't do it!". Sometimes used as prefix: avgaro

trans.def: brown, swart, dark brown, golden brown, yellow brown

entry.note: In the Etymologies, the word for `bread' is given as bast, Quenya masta, but it seems that Tolkien later changed his mind and updated the word to bass, as shown in Quenya massánie, Sindarin besain, besoneth `bread-giver'. These later Sindarin forms are however dubious; we would rather have expected bessain (as a regular cognate of Quenya massánie) and bassoneth (without i-affection)
See bass for a discussion regarding this word
See bass for a discussion regarding this word
The Etymologies seem to list this word as a noun, but it is clearly the third person singular of the verb

trans.def: old, that has long endured, or been established, or in use
to serve, to hold allegiance to
to serve, to hold allegiance to

entry.note: Emended by Tolkien from earlier cabad. This is our sole late example that basic verbs should perhaps form their gerund in -ed, whereas derived verbs are well attested to use -ad (cf. aderthad)
This word is indeclinable, according to the Etymologies

trans.def: fence or palisade of spikes and sharp stakes
elf of the Great Journey (lit. `light person'), by ext. all elves but the Avari
`quarter', silver coin used in Gondor, the fourth part of a `mirian' (q.v.)
tressure, net for combining the hair
like silver, in hue or worth
cleft, high climbing pass, narrow passage cut through earth or rock
pippin (seed of certain fruits, or more probably small red apple)
kind of crow of large size, raven
cake of compressed flour or meal (often containing honey and milk)

entry.note: In Tolkien's manuscript, this form was rejected in favor of dangweth, with a slightly different meaning. However, it must assumed that the word is valid per se.
No language indication in the Etymologies, but Noldorin from context and phonological evidence

trans.def: the Nandor (a tribe of elves), the people of Denwe
man (archaic), referring to an adult male (elf, mortal, or of any other speaking race)
a military wedge-formation launched over a short distance against an enemy massing but not yet arrayed, or against a defensive formation on open ground
land, dwelling-place, region where certain people live
heavy stroke, a blow (e.g. of axe)
clenched fist, hence also `blow with fist'

entry.note: Only the imperative drego is attested. Therefore, the verb may also be dreg- (inf. dregi)

trans.def: the people of the Drû (q.v.), the woses

entry.etym: Either the collective plural of dû, or a compound dû+gwath "night shade" (hence dúwath)

trans.def: elf of Beleriand (including Noldor and Sindar), lit. `elf of the west'
a season, the beginning of spring (lit. `stirring')

entry.note: The sentence from WR/293 is hardly legible and is not translated, but this word is however a plausible form.
Actually, edlothiand might be a misreading, according to David Salo who checked the original manuscript at Marquette and reported that his reading was unmistakably edlothiad

trans.def: `one forsaken', an elf of the Falathrim
`one forsaken', an elf of the Falathrim
to prick with a sharp point, to stab
star (archaic, little used except in verses)
a flower, a kind of enlarged pimpernel bearing golden and silver flowers
starry host, all the host of the stars of heaven
an exclamation of wonder, admiration, delight

entry.note: The proper word for first in Sindarin was minui

entry.etym: OS *oroni- (plural noun, used as a singular) (ÓR-ON)

trans.def: hope, trust, a temper of mind, steady fixed in purpose, and difficult to dissuade and unlikely to fall into despair or abandon its purpose
the Avari, a tribe of elves

entry.note: This plural name was known to the loremasters, but went out of daily use at the time of the Exile

trans.def: fair minded, just, generous (etym. `having a good fëa')
the `Shore-language' (one of the names for Common Speech)
cloud (applied to clouds, floating as veils over the blue sky or the sun or moon, or resting on hills)
night, dead of night, gloom, darkness
radiance, glittering, reflection (from jewels, glass or polished metal, or water)

entry.note: Ety/357, S/427, LotR/E, LB/354, RGEO/73, Letters/426

trans.def: pipe-weed (leaf) or `westmansweed', a variety of Nicotiana
blessings(?), blessedness(?), good fortune(?) (meaning not entirely clear)
a black metal devised by the dark elf Eöl
stopgap, name of a diacritic sign used to indicate that g had been lenited to zero
worn, old, decripit (used of things only)

entry.note: Written glær (with ae-ligature) in the Etymologies

trans.def: din, uproar, the confused yelling and bellowing of beasts (so firmly associated with orcs that it could be used alone of any body of orcs)
barbaric host of orcs, lit. `the dinhorde, the yelling horde'
hem, border (of textile and other hand-made things)

entry.note: Glanduin, Glanhír UT/264, UT/318, UT/441, VT/42:8

trans.def: golden light (of the golden tree Laurelin)
sunlight, radiance (of the golden tree Laurelin)

entry.note: This entry should perhaps read gleinia-, cf. VT/42:28, note 13

trans.def: gleam, glint (usually of fine slender but bright shafts of light); particularly applied to light of eyes

entry.note: The form glintha- is theorically impossible in Sindarin, and can only be regarded as an (earlier) Old Sindarin form: according to our current understanding of the Sindarin phonology, it should evolve into glinna-

trans.def: to sing, trill, to recite a poem
to sing, trill, to recite a poem
`deep elf' or `gnome', one of the wise folk
`deep elf' or `gnome', one of the wise folk
inflorescence, a head of small flowers
to count, count up, reckon, sum up
magic, `long study' (being used mostly of secret knowledge, especially such as possessed by artificers who made wonderful things)
perverted or evil knowledge, sorcery, necromancy

entry.note: Apparently the word gûr with a suffixed possessive. See lammen for a similar form

trans.def: together (only in old compounds; the living form is go-)
brother (especially used of those not brothers by blood, but sworn brothers or associates)
death (act of dying, not death as a state or abstract)
death (act of dying, not death as a state or abstract)
a twin (one of a pair of twins)

entry.etym: OS *watt&suph;e, CE *wahtê, blended with OS *gwat&suph;a (WAH, GWATH)

trans.def: The dunlendings or people of Dunland
air, lower air (distinct from the `upper' air of the stars, or the `outer')
man power, troop of able-bodied men, host, regiment
`foam', properly a flying spume or spindrift blown off wavetops

entry.etym: Backformed from OS *sk&suph;apati, plural of *sk&suph;apa; CE *sk&supj;apat (SKJAP)

entry.note: It might also be sabar (q.v.), mutated in composition
Written hæw (with ae-ligature) in the Etymologies

trans.def: to retain, keep, do not give away or release, keep hold of

entry.note: Because of the mutation triggered by the first person pronominal ending, it is impossible to guess whether the stem of this should be heb-, *hab- or *hob-. The root KHEP listed in VT/41:6 apparently implies that heb- is the correct form

The form helta- in the Etymologies is either a misprint or a misreading, unless the word is actually meant to be Quenya (and in that case, a Q is missing before the entry). Its Sindarin cognate would anyway still be heltha-

trans.def: child (mostly used as a prefix in patronymics or metronymics)
mist-thread, a substance used by the elves of Lothlórien to make strong ropes

entry.note: It might also be sollen (q.v.), mutated in adjectival position

trans.def: host, crowd, horde (nearly always in a bad sense)
readiness for action, vigour, fiery spirit

entry.note: It originally meant `bridge' in the Etymologies, but was apparently switched with iant
Stated to be an alteration of sell, remodelled after ion "son" (OS *jondo). It was "a change assisted by the loss of s in compounds and patronymics", hence the ending -iel in several feminine words
Compare with Q imbe in Galadriel's lament

trans.def: narrow valley with steep sides, deep valley

entry.note: This word only occurs in the place name Imloth Melui, a vale where roses grew

trans.def: long narrow valley with a road or watercourse running through it lengthwise
old (of person, in mortal sense: decripit, suffering from old age)

entry.note: New word coined by the elves after meeting with men

entry.etym: MS *inw (reformed after CS anu, MS *anw), OS *inia (INI)

trans.def: aged, long-lived, old (with no connotation of weakness)
a silver-colored substance, which `mirrors only starlight and moonlight'

entry.note: The gloss was hardly legible. Christopher Tolkien reads `to enjoy' but the meaning `to employ' is much more probable (cf. iuith)
The word is classed as Old Noldorin (ON) in the Etymologies, but rather seems to be Noldorin

The reading Eithel Ivrin in S/392 seems erroneous and should probably be corrected into the plural Eithil Ivrin as in WJ/85, unless Ivrin is actually a proper noun (Eithil Ivrin is rendered as "Ivrin's Well", see WJ/139). The meaning is interpolated from the description of this place in various sources: `crystal fountains' (Lay of Húrin, verse 1526), `reflecting their pallid faces' (ibid., verse 2177), `glassy pools' ( Lay of Leithian, verses 1932-1940)
This entry is interpolated from Sador's nickname, Labadal, which is rendered as "Hopafoot" in the text

trans.def: deep elf (Sindarin name for the Ñoldor)
the people of the green elves

entry.note: There was a long controverse between linguists, as to know whether this form was and adjective ("of the tongue, related to the tongue") or the word lam with a suffixed possessive ("my"). See guren for a similar form

trans.def: sharp edge (not of tools), suddend end ("as e.g. a cliff-edge, or the clean edge of things made by hand or built")
animal, usually applied to four-footed beasts, and never to reptiles or birds
a tree - its black wood was used by the woodwrights of Gondor
ears (referring to one person's pair of ears only)
I will sing, I will chant
a single verse used as a maxim(?)
ashen, ashy, of ash, ash-coloured, dusty
flower, inflorescence, a head of small flowers

entry.note: The noun is collective, a single flower being lotheg

trans.def: sharp, piercing, penetrating, going deep in something
battle, fight (not of general host but of two or a few)

entry.note: The word megil (q.v.), probably introduced by the Ñoldor, was also used

trans.def: first, only in the sense of 'prime, chief, pre-eminent'

entry.note: The word was struck out in the Etymologies, but is well attested in late compounds such as Mormegil or Arvegil (with regular mutation). It is conceivably the Sindarinized form of Quenya makil, coexisting with magol (see tegil and tegol for a similar case)
This word only occurs in the place name Imloth Melui, a vale where roses grew

trans.def: sky, high heaven, firmament, the region of the stars

entry.note: The word was changed to beren in the Etymologies, but meren would be restored together with mereth
The word was changed to bereth in the Etymologies, but was never changed in the texts (cf. Mereth Aderthad and the compound Merethrond)

trans.def: fort, city with a citadel and central watch-tower
isolated hill, especially a hill with a watch tower
an elf, one of the Vanyar
`morrowdim', the time near dawn, when the star fade

entry.note: Ety/373, LotR/E, S/434, PM/348, LB/354, RGEO/73

trans.def: piece of money, coin used in Gondor, see also `canath'
one of the Avari or Easterlings in Beleriand
shadow (of objects, cast by light), dark shapes

entry.note: Ety/373, Letters/382, Letters/427, WJ/368, WR/113, UT/65
The Etymologies list this word as the past tense of the verb mudo, but actually it looks more like a noun
The Etymologies list mudas as the past tense of this this verb, but actually this form looks more like a noun "labour, toil"

trans.def: with, by (also used as a genitive sign)
woe (gets senses of gnashing teeth in grief)
any formation or projection tapering to a point: a spearhead, gore, wedge, narrow promontory, triangle
a tale or a saga, that is told in verse to be spoken and not sung
in, of (time, e.g. giving a date)

entry.note: Hammond and Scull apparently understand this word as a derivative of neledh "three", hence their translation neledh neledhi "three by three". However, we have shown in Hiswelókë (third issue, pp. 74-78) that this word is conceivably a verb derived from LED "to go". The prefix ne- also occurs in nestegi "to insert, stick in"

trans.def: water (used of a lake, pool or lesser river)

entry.note: The acute accent in nín is probably an error for a slanted macron in the manuscript. The other attested personal adjectives all have a circumflex accent. If the acute accent is confirmed, then this word would probably be enclitic, see HL/73
With suffixed article, see also nuin

trans.def: to stunt, to prevent from coming to completion, stop short, not allow to continue
from, of; preposition (as a proclitic) used in either direction, from or to the point of view of the speaker

entry.note: According to WJ/366, the preposition "is normally o in all positions, though od appears occasionally before vowels, especially before o-". With a suffixed article, see also uin

The Etymologies state that h- is prefixed to the word following this preposition, when it begins in a vowel: o Hedhil "concerning the elves (Edhil)". Some scholars consider that this rule is not valid in Sindarin, but that the preposition would perhaps become oh in such a case (hence oh Edhil, to be compared with ah in Athrabeth Finrod ah Andreth

trans.def: `deep elf' or `gnome', one of the wise folk

entry.note: Written onen in some editions of LotR

trans.def: seventh day of the Númenórean week, Sea-day
second day of the week, day of the Sun
sixth day of the week, day of the Powers or Valar

entry.note: Ety/379, LR/406, WJ/390, LotR/II:VI, LotR/F, Letters/178

trans.def: fourth day of the Númenórean week, day of the White Tree

entry.note: This day was formerly called orgaladhad in the Elvish calendar

trans.def: fourth day of the Elvish week, day of the Two Trees

entry.note: This day was renamed orgaladh in the Númenórean calendar
entry.etym: aur+galadh, with quenya influenced dual ending

trans.def: first day of the week, day of the Stars
third day of the week, day of the Moon
fifth day of the week, Heavens' day
mountaineer, one living in the mountains
fortress or stronghold, made or strenghtened by art
fortress or city in underground caves, underground stronghold
plank, fixed board, especially in floor

entry.note: As no other word beginning in ph- is attested, it is assumed that a nasal mutation is triggered by the pronoun în, hence the form observed in the "King's Letter"

trans.def: fist (often used to mean `hand'; its chief use was in reference of the tighly closed hand, as in using an implement or a craft-tool, rather than to the fist used in punching)
passage up or down slope, stairway
to make a way, find a way
to make a way, find a way
wing (horn), extended point at side, etc.
horn (especially on living animal, but also applied to mountains)
horn (especially on living animal, but also applied to mountains)
a powerful, hostile and terrible creature, a demon
mesh, net (esp. for catching, hunter's or fisher's net)

entry.note: The reading of the gloss is uncertain

trans.def: vaulted or arched roof, as seen from below (and usually not visible from outside), or a (large) hall of chamber so roofed
red-haired, copper coloured, especially used of animals, as fox, red deer, etc.

entry.note: The unmutated form is reconstructed from the place name Nornhabar, assuming that the second word is mutated in composition. However habar as the regular form might be possible as well

trans.def: limited area naturally or artificially defined, a place, spot

entry.note: Sador was Túrin's faithful servant. The meaning of this noun is deduced from sadron, assuming that these words are in the same kind of relation as hador and hadron

trans.def: garden, field, yard, or other place in private ownership whether enclosed or not

entry.note: Sern in UT/463 is a misprint, see VT/42:11

trans.def: to set aside, appropriate to a special purpose or owner

entry.note: This demonstrative adjective is probably enclitic. It has been suggested that this possibility could perhaps explain why the mutated form of tîw on the Doors of Durin is thiw instead of the expected thîw, see HL/69

trans.def: `Blood of Stone', a plant with deep red flowers that grew on Amon Rûdh

entry.note: The unmutated form is reconstructed from the place name Fen Hollen, assuming that the word, used in adjectival position, is mutated. However hollen as the regular form might be possible as well: it could be expected to be mutated likewise (into *chollen), but on the other hand the example of Nen Hithoel seems to show that words beginning with an h may resist to the lenition
Deduced from Arassuil, conceivably aran+suil. For the meaning, see suilad
Written tær (with ae-ligature) in the Etymologies
Normalized to tafnen, as for lefnui

trans.def: second, in the sense 'supporting, second in command'

entry.note: tad-dail WJ/388, Ety/390, S/429, S/437, X/EI

trans.def: wooden platform (in the trees of Lothlórien where the Galadhrim dwelt)
king (only used of the legitimate kings of whole tribes)
mighty, vast, overwhelming, huge, awful, high, sublime

entry.etym: OS *tåra, CE *târâ, and OS *taura (TAR, blended with TUR)

entry.note: Sindarized form of Quenya tekil, not known to the Sindar until the coming of the Ñoldor (but see however tegol for a possible dialectal variant)

It is stated in PM/318 that "tegil was a Sindarized form of Quenya tekil `pen', not known to the Sindar until the coming of the Ñoldor". It must be assumed therefore that tegol was either rejected by Tolkien, or that it may perhaps have been considered as a dialectal variant. For a similar case where both a true Sindarin/Noldorin word and a Sindarized form conceivably coexist, see magol and megil "sword" (it is unlikely that weapons were not known to the Sindar)

trans.def: an elf, one of the Teleri
the Teleri, a tribe of elves
hero, dauntless man (`especially as surname of Húrin Thalion')
shield-fence, a battle formation of the Dúnedain
to intend, mean, purpose, resolve, will
one who remains firm in his purpose

entry.note: The Etymologies erroneously class this word as Quenya

trans.def: to fade, to grow towards evening

entry.note: The punctuation in The Etymologies is considered incorrect (the full dot after this word should conceivably be a comma)

trans.def: `shortness', name of mark indicating short quality of vowel

entry.etym: Back-formed from the plural, see thôr (THOR-ON)

trans.def: to watch, to gaze, look at
to watch, to gaze, look at
to watch, to gaze, look at
to watch, to gaze, look at
island, isle rising with sheer sides from the sea or from a river

entry.note: According to WJ/301, the expression tôl acharn "vengeance comes" was later changed to tûl acharn by Tolkien
Tolkien emended toloth to tolodh, cf. VT/42:31. If we are to follow him, a word such as tolothen would be incorrect, unless the two forms coexisted

trans.def: to fetch, to summon, make come
to fetch, to summon, make come

entry.note: The word is muindor is more usual

trans.def: bush, low-growing tree (as maple, hawthorn, blackthorn, holly, etc.)
shire, administrative district, division of a realm
`through', but denoting completeness when prefixed to verbs; cf. English idioms like `talk something through'
to recount, to tell to end
to recount, to tell to end

entry.etym: OS *tuia-, blend of CE *tiuja- and CE *tuja- (TIW, TUJ)

trans.def: deep valley, under or among hills
envelope, especially of the Outer Sea or Air enfolding the world within the Ilurambar or world-walls

entry.note: Normalized to uidafnen, as in lefnui

trans.def: always white, ever white as snow
a small white everlasting flower also called simbelmynë, alfirin, `evermind'

entry.note: The word is classed as Old Noldorin (ON) in the Etymologies, but rather seems to be Noldorin
